question: Which is the commonest ocular manifestation of Tuberculosis?
exp: Phlyctenular conjunctivitis used to be most common manifestation of tuberculosis, but now it is causes by staphylococcus Eales' disease (periphlebitis retinae ) occur in tuberculosis but it is not very common. Acute retinal necrosis occurs in Herpes simplex and varicella infection not in tuberculosis. Choroiditis is by far the most common manifestation of tuberculosis.
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: Which of the following ophthalmological anomaly is seen in WAGR syndrome
exp: Some impoant syndromes and their associations to be remembered Down's syndrome: Congenital cataract Rubella Syndrome: Congenital Cataract WAGR Syndrome: Aniridia Gillepsie syndrome: Aniridia FRASER Syndrome: Cryptophthalmos Marfan's syndrome: Subluxation of lens Patau Syndrome: PHPV

question: A 75 year old lady wakes up with sudden painless loss of vision. She gives history of scalp tenderness and cramp like pain on eating. O/E there is a pale disc edema, has an inferior altitudinal field defect. What is the likely cause?
exp: Symptoms of GCA -such as Headache and tenderness of the temporal aeries and scalp. Jaw claudication, characterized by pain on speaking or chewing, is pathognomonic of GCA, caused by ischaemia of masseter muscle Other symptoms include fever, malaise, anorexia, weight loss, night sweats and joint and muscle pain. GCA is extremely unlikely under 55-60 years. It constitutes an ophthalmic emergency.
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: Normal pH of tears is:
exp: Tear film consists of - Innermost mucinous layer lining the conjunctival cells and corneal epithelium secreted by the goblet cells, Middle aqueous layer secreted by the lacrimal and accessory conjunctival glands of Krause. Outermost superficial lipid layer secreted by the meibomian glands which are veically oriented sebaceous glands found within the tarsal plate and limits the evaporation of tears. physical chracterstics of tear film- Ph=6. 5 to 7. 6; the mean value was 7. 0. Refractive index= 1. 375 basal rate of production-1. 2ul/min
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: Which of the following abnormalities are not commonly seen with chloroquine toxicity
exp: Ocular Manifestations of chloroquine toxicity a. Whorl like opacities in cornea b. Macular pigmentation c. Scotoma d. Posterior subcapsular cataract e. ERG EEG abnormalities f. Hudson stahl line
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: Which is the most common ocular manifestation of Thyroid Eye disease?
exp: Lid signs: Retraction of the upper lids producing the characteristic staring and frightened appearance (Dalrymple's sign); Lid lag (von Graefe's sign) i. e., when globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind Fullness of eyelids due to puffy oedematous swelling (Enroth's sign) Difficulty in eversion of upper lid (Gifford's sign). Most common amongst these is lid retraction producing the characteristic staring look.
opc: Congestion of blood vessels over the inseion of the lateral rectus
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: Which of the following can not be diagnosed on direct ophthalmoscopy
exp: Angle recession cannot be diagnosed by direct ophthalmoscopy Diseases that can be diagnosed by Direct Ophthalmoscope Location of cataract (distant direct ophthalmoscopy) Diabetic retinopathy Hypeensive retinopathy Age-related macular degeneration Fundus dystrophies Optic neuritis Papilledema Glaucoma Comprehensive Ophthalmology, 6th edition, A K Khurana, Pg 590
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: Normal value of Schirmer's test should be at least:
exp: Schirmer's test- It measure total tear secretions. It is performed with the help of a 5*35mm strip of whatman-41 filter paper which is folded 5mm from one end and kept in the lower fornix at the junction of lateral one third and medial two third. The patient is asked to look up and not to blink or close the eyes. After 5 minutes wetting of filter paper strip from the bent end is measured. Normal values of schimer test are more than 15mm values of 5-10mm are suggestive of moderate to mild keratoconjuctivitis sicca Less than 5mm are suggestive of severe keratoconjuctivitis.
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: Which drug should be avoided in the management of traumatic hyphema in a dark race individual?
exp: Traumatic hyphema presents with raised intraocular pressure. Timolol will help to control raised IOP. Atropine will provide cycloplegic action and will provide relief from pain. Steroids will help to prevent rebleed. Acetazolamide is not given in dark race patients due to risk of sickling as a result of metabolic acidosis caused by acetazolamide.
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: A 32 year old male presents with unilateral diminished vision in the right eye. On examination, there is mild iritis, vitritis and focal necrotic lesion is seen at macula. The most likely diagnosis is:-
exp: The most common protozoal infection in adults is toxoplasmosis. The most common means of toxoplasmosis infection in the eye is through reactivation of trophozoites, primary infection occurs in the fetal life. The history strongly suggests toxoplasmosis as there is NECROTIC lesion in the retina with vitritis.
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: Which clinical feature of differentiates orbital apex syndrome (OAS) from superior orbital fissure syndrome (SOFS)?
exp: Proptosis and loss of ocular movements can occur in both. Horner syndrome is more likely a feature of cavernous sinus syndrome which differentiates it from superior orbital fissure syndrome. As orbital apex syndrome affects optic canal, it causes loss of vision which differentiates it from SOFS.
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics

question: The conversion of CO2 &H20 into carbonic acid in the formation of aqueous humour is catalyzed by which enzymes:
exp: mechansim of Aqueous production- diffusion-Main mechanism, energy dependent process ultra-filtration Active secretion Ultrafiltration, most of the plasma substances pass out from thecapillary wall. Active Secretion Paired Na+/H+and Cl-/HCO3-antipos actively transpos Na+ and Cl- from the stroma into the cells. Intercellular gap junctions also play critical rule. The tight junctions between the cells of the non-pigment epithelium create pa of blood aqueous barrier. Ceain substances are actively transpoed (secreted) across this barrier into posterior chamber. The active transpo is brought about by Na+ -K+ activated ATPase pump, calcium and voltage gated ion channels and carbonic anhydrase enzyme system. Diffusion. Active transpo of these substances across the non-pigmented ciliary epithelium results in an osmotic gradient leading to the movement of other plasma constituents into the posterior chamber Formation of aqueous humour
topic_name: Investigation in ophthalmology and miscellaneous topics
